titleproper.value: Guide to the Westbeth Playwrights' Feminist Collective Records<lb/>1971-2015 (bulk, 1971-1975)<lb/> <num>MS 3056</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-06-25T13:17:36</date>

abstract.value: Records of the short-lived but groundbreaking Westbeth Playwrights' Feminist Collective, one of the earliest feminist theater groups in the United States. Incorporated 1972 and dissolved 1976, the WPFC was headquartered at the historic Westbeth Artists' Housing on West Street, Manhattan, and produced plays by feminist authors focused on issues central to the women's movement like sexual harassment and workplace inequality. The collection includes scripts, publicity material, articles and reviews, some correspondence, ephemera, and photographs of select production scenes and WPFC members.

p.value: <emph render="bold">Note</emph>: Until the audio tapes in box 2, folders 6 and 10 have been preservation reformatted, they may not be played.
This collection should be cited as the Westbeth Playwrights' Feminist Collective Records, MS 3056, The New-York Historical Society.

[This note is drawn from information in the collection, as well as the <extref actuate="onRequest" href=" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westbeth_Playwrights_Feminist_Collective ">WPFC Wikipedia page</extref>, which supplies a detailed chronology of productions and credits for writing, directing, cast, and staging support.]

Although the Westbeth Playwrights' Feminist Collective Records contain scattered materials dating from as recently as 2015, the bulk of the collection stems from the period of the organization's existence, 1971–1975. It includes foundational documents (certificate of incorporation; petition for dissolution; see box 1, folder 2), information on grants received from the New York State Council on the Arts (box 1, folder 4), correspondence (box 1, folder 3), and photographs of members and select productions (box 1, folder 5). Most of the other items document WPFC productions through small-format posters, flyers, and programs (box 1, folder 6; box 3, folder 6), press releases (box 3, folder 4), and articles and reviews (box 1, folder 1). Production-specific materials include scripts, box office reports, and, in two cases, tape recordings of music for the performances (box 2, folders 6 and 10). [Note that until these tapes have been preservation reformatted, they may not be played.] Many of the WPFC productions were multi-authored revues, or series of short sketches; some scripts are lacking, and these have been noted by the donor (see the container list, box 2, folders 5–9).

dsc.value:
Articles and reviews2322091972-197511Scope and Contents

Includes color photographs of WPFC founding member Dolores Walker reading at the site of the 1911 Triangle Shirtwaist Fire (23–29 Washington Place) and outside the Public Theater (425 Lafayette Street) as part of the march anticipating the production of "Jumpin' Salty" (see box 3, folder 2).

[Certificate of Incorporation, tax exempt status, grants, dissolution]2321821972-197612Correspondence2321831972-2011 (bulk, 1972-1974)13Scope and Contents

A number of the letters are from educators and college students seeking information on the WPFC's productions and available scripts. Includes correspondence and contracts for readings and workshops sponsored by Poets and Writers, Inc.

New York State Council on the Arts2321841972-197514Scope and Contents

The WPFC was partially funded by the New York State Council on the Arts. Folder includes projected budgets, financial statements, author biographies, and filing instructions.

Photographs2322151971-2015 (bulk, 1971-1975)15Scope and Contents

Includes images of WPFC productions such as "Rape-In" (1971), "? ! A Revue" (1973), and "Wicked Women Revue" (1973), photographs of WPFC members at the time of the Collective's existence (1971-1975), and a color print of Marjorie Melnick, Christina Maile, Gwendolyn Gunn, Dolores Walker, Nancy Rhodes, and Helen Duberstein, taken during a 2015 interview.

Posters, flyers, chronology, programs2321861972-197516Scope and Contents

Small-format signage for most of the WPFC's productions, programs, and workshops.

[Print matter] | The Drama Review, vol. 16, no. 22322431972 June17Scope and Contents

Coverage of WPFC pp. 87-89: Charlotte Rea, "Women's Theatre Groups. (Photocopies of article also in box 1, folder 1.)

[Print matter] | Ms., vol. 1, no. 22322441972 August21Scope and Contents

Coverage of WPFC pp. 17-22: Sondra Lowell, "The New Feminist Theater." (Photocopies of article also in box 1, folder 1.)

[Print matter] | VIVA: The International Magazine for Women, vol. 1, no. 82322461974 May22Scope and Contents

Coverage of WPFC p. 39: Margaret Croyden, "Women Directors and Playwrights." (Photocopies of article also in box 1, folder 1.)

[Print matter] | Janet Brown, Feminist Drama: Definition & Critical Analysis (Scarecrow Press)232241197923Scope and Contents

References to WPFC pp. 87-89, 94-95, 101, 104.

[Print matter] | Christopher Olsen, Off-Off Broadway. The Second Wave: 1968-1980 (self published)232235201124Scope and Contents

Chapter 5, "Theatres with a Gender Focus," includes a section on WPFC, pp. 159-162.

[Production] | "Rape-In"2322211971 May25Scope and Contents

Contains scripts for "There's a Wall Between Us Darling" (Sally Ordway), "Abide in Darkness" (Dolores Walker), "Across the Street" (Gwendolyn Gunn), and "The Prisoner -- A Monologue" (Chryse Maile). Includes a note on missing scripts.

[Production] | "Up! An Uppity Revue"2322201972 February26Scope and Contents

Contains lyrics and recorded music (in the form of a reel of magnetic tape), and scripts for "Family, Family" (Sally Ordway), "Daddy's Little Girl" (Dolores Walker), "The Interview" (Dolores Walker and A. Piotrowski), "Turning the Tables" (Patricia Horan), "Propositions" (Susan Yankowitz), "Some of Your Biggies" (Patricia Horan), "A Few Concessions" (Patricia Horan), and "The Confessions of Clara" (Gwendolyn Gunn). Includes a note on missing scripts.

Restrictions

Until the audio tape in this file has been preservation reformatted, it may not be played.

[Production] | "Wicked Women Revue"2322241973 January27Scope and Contents

Contains scripts for "Subway" (Patricia Horan), "Egos" (Patricia Horan), "Playthings" (Sally Ordway), "The Appetizer" (Dolores Walker), "Fly You, a.k.a. Fly Me" (Gwendolyn Gunn), "Promise Her Anything" (Sally Ordway), "I Want Your Heart, a.k.a. Hearts & Flowers" (Dolores Walker and A. Piotrowski), and "Animal Monologues" (Susan Yankowitz). Includes a note on missing scripts.

[Production] | "? ! A Revue"2322251973 May28Scope and Contents

Contains scripts for "Oh Muse, Where Art Thou, Muse?" (Sally Ordway), "The Interview" (Dolores Walker and A. Piotrowski), "Museum of Mannequins" (Chyrse Maile), "Playthings" (Sally Ordway), "Family, Family" (Sally Ordway), "Daisy Snaps" (Chryse Maile), "Marathon" (Gwendolyn Gunn), "The Play Called Michigan" (Chryse Maile), and an untitled scene by Chryse Maile. Includes a note on missing scripts.

[Production] | "We Can Feed Everybody Here"2322231974 January29Scope and Contents

Contains scripts for "Dorie Play" (Chryse Maile), "Among the Relics - The Gynecologist" (Gwendolyn Gunn), "Duet, a.k.a. Duet for Two Women" (Megan Terry), "Sex Wars - Matriarchy to Patriarchy" (Sally Ordway), and "Intelligent Life in the Universe" (Chryse Maile). Includes a note on missing scripts.

[Production] | "What Time of Night It Is" [2 folders]2322181974 May210-11Scope and Contents

Includes script by Patricia Horan and Marjorie DeFazio, a cassette tape of music (restricted), budget sheets, production materials, fliers, programs, box office reports, and reviews.

Restrictions

Until the cassette tape in this file (folder 10) has been preservation reformatted, it may not be played.

[Production] | "Medea" 2322281975 January31Scope and Contents

Contains fliers, programs, production materials, and correspondence with author Gloria Albee.

[Production] | "Jumpin' Salty" 2322261975 April32Scope and Contents

Contains scripts for "Witnessing" (Dolores Walker), "Lena Horne Bites Her Tongue" (Chryse Maile), "Mabel Dodge" (Sally Ordway), "The Laundry Workers Present: Hatpin Bessie" (Linda Kline), "Willa-Willie-Bill's Dope Garden (a meditation in one act on Willa Cather)" (Megan Terry), "Margaret Sanger" (Gwendolyn Gunn), "Eartha Kitt Dressed in a White Fur Coat" (Chryse Maile). Also includes production materials, box office reports, and press clippings.

[Production] | "The Mother of Us All" 2322301976 April-May33Scope and Contents

Contains fliers, programs, reviews, and a photocopy of a letter from the composer Virgil Thomson to Nancy Rhodes, thanking the WPFC for producing his opera, based on the life of Susan B. Anthony and scored to a libretto by Gertrude Stein.

Publicity 2322121971-197534Scope and Contents

Press releases and articles (many duplicated elsewhere in the collection).

Stationery 232214[1971-1975]35Scope and Contents

Blank letterhead and envelopes with WPFC logo and names of playwrights (Gwendolyn Gunn, Patricia Horan, Chryse Maile, Sally Ordway, Dolores Walker, Susan Yankowitz), and board of sponsors (Margaret Croyden, Alice Denham, Elizabeth Fisher, Ellen Frankfort, Carol Greitzer, Tania [the artist born Tatiana Lewin], Florynce Kennedy, Eleanor Perry, Muriel Rukeyser, Alix Shulman, Anita Steckel, Gloria Steinem).

Workshops and programs 2322111972-197436Scope and Contents

Announcements and fliers for workshops and programs produced and sponsored by the WPFC.
